title: Why Boost to a Rank You Don't Belong In?
body:
I cannot understand why people want to be higher ranked than they should be.  It's not going to get you a better job, and your friends know that you're bad, no matter how high your rank is.  The only people you're "impressing" are the other, similarly ranked folks on your team - who are NOT impressed, especially when they see how bad you are.  You are ruining every future game for yourself and 9 other random strangers.  

So what is the psychology behind getting a higher rank?  Bragging rights?  To whom?  Yourself?

There's also the ego part of it. Some people think they're better than others and want to prove it, but their actual skill keeps them at the rank they belong in. They think they belong in Chaneljour, but they're not actually any better than Bronze or Silver.

Sometimes, to be fair, it isn't boosting to a rank you don't belong in, it's just boosting you to a more proper rank faster (as opposed to playing 100's of games). Especially since it's incredibly frustrating to lose games in an elo much lower than your actual skill when you get the worse team. 

The other aspect is that because there are so many factors that affect a games outcome, a player might actually find success in a higher elo where they found defeat in a lower one. 

Of course that doesn't justify it, just giving some perspective. It took me 4 years to get my main to plat, and games actually got easier and less frustrating the higher i climbed. That's because over 4 years i had developed quite a bit of game knowledge, but not necessarily the skill to match it, making it really frustrating when i knew what needs to be done at every point of the game, but not actually good enough to carry a team that refused to do it.

Process vs Outcome orientation:

Turns out people are different. Who knew?

Some people really value the process or "journey" that is required to reach a goal. Some people value the process so much that the end result's value, in their eyes, can change depending on what the process used was. An extreme example of this is seen in the common saying, "It doesn't matter if you win or lose. Its how you play the game".

Other people care less about the process and focus more heavily on the goal or outcome; way the reach the goal matters less or sometimes doesn't matter at all. "Win at ANY cost" is the extreme end of this thought.

Neither way of thinking is INHERENTLY  better or worse, good or bad. It is a subjective thing.

People who value outcomes more than they do the process are more likely to cheat. I admit that that is a major oversimplification of the situation but I don't want to type too much more so don't flip out please.

Player A is willing to be boosted because the vast majority of the value, to HIM, is obtaining the objective award. Getting the border, ward skin, etc. He isn't bothered by the fact that he really isn't "that good" because he doesn't value the actual skill. It's all about the outcome.

Is it wrong for him to value the border more than the skill? No.

Is it wrong for him to get boosted in order to get the border? It is certainly against Riot's ToS.

I'm not claiming that this is the absolute truth in every scenerio. I'm just applying the "process vs outcome" concept from psychology to the OPs context.

Idiotic teammates, getting stuck playing vs premades, elo hell, etc, do exist, but they will never actually stop someone from climbing if they are better than their rank.
